episode.title: Episode 434
episode.description: Interview with Chris Mooney and Indre Viskontas; This Day in Skepticism: Carl Sagan, Florence Rena Sabin; News Items: Tardis Science, Moving Stones, Blushing in the Dark, Rock Paper Scissors Robot; Who's That Noisy; Swindler's List: Kevin Trudeau; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "If we go back to the beginnings of things, we shall always find that ignorance and fear created the gods; that imagination, rapture and deception embellished them; that weakness worships them; that custom spares them; and that tyranny favors them in order to profit from the blindness of men."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A new long term study of astronauts finds that prolonged exposure to microgravity may reverse atherosclerotic changes in blood vessels.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers have found that playing rock or pop music increases the efficiency of one type of solar cell by 40%.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Orthopedic surgeons have identified a previously unknown ligament in the human knee.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Happy birthday to Carl Sagan and Florence Rena Sabin
Swindler's List: Kevin Trudeau's Legal Troubles
Interview with Chris Mooney and Indre Viskontas
Announcements: Special appearance by Steven Novella

episode.title: Episode 433
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Charles Van Doren; News Items: Ghost Story, Lorenzo’s Oil, Space Ports, Li Fi, Gender; Who's That Noisy; Live Questions: Getting Involved in Skepticism; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Seeking what it true is not seeking what is desirable."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: In the past week astronomers have recorded the largest solar flare every directly observed.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds that playing immersive video-games increases a player’s tolerance for pain and reduces their empathy for the pain of others.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Neuroscientists have discovered a new type of information processing in the brain that significantly increases the brain’s computing power.

episode.title: Episode 432
episode.description: Interview with Brian Malow; This Day in Skepticism: Baby Fae; News Items: 1000 Exoplanets, Scientific Literacy and the Tea Party, PPMOs, Wind turbine Syndrome; Who's that Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The pursuit of balance can create imbalance because sometimes something is true."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A computer engineer has developed an algorithm to restore a digital image from as little as 1% of the original information.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds that younger siblings may contain cells with the DNA of their older siblings.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Researchers find that eucalyptus trees concentrate gold in their leaves, and in some areas represent a significant source of the mineral.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Baby Fae has a baboon heart transplanted
Scientific Literacy and the Tea Party

episode.title: Episode 431
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Johnnetta Cole; News Items: Money Predicts Apocalypse, Herbal Supplements, Politics and Dogma, Singularity vs Bridge; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Cooling Drinks; Name That Logical Fallacy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "...academic credentials are neither a necessary nor a sufficient condition for having your ideas taken seriously. If a famous professor repeatedly says stupid things, then tries to claim he never said them, there’s no rule against calling him a mendacious idiot — and no special qualifications required to make that pronouncement other than doing your own homework.Conversely, if someone without formal credentials consistently makes trenchant, insightful observations, he or she has earned the right to be taken seriously, regardless of background."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A single brown bat can consume 1,200 mosquito-size insects in one hour.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: The sucker footed bat from Madagascar attaches to palm leaves by suction cups on its wings and ankles.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Bats are the most common source of human rabies in the Americas, but this is still rare, only causing 1-2 cases per year in the US.

item.title: Item #4
item.description: Draculin is an anticoagulant (blood-thinner) purified from the saliva of vampire bats.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Johnnetta Cole

episode.title: Episode 430
episode.description: Interview with Marty Klein; This Day in Skepticism: Chicago Fire; News Items: 2013 Nobel Prizes, Kansas Citizens Oppose Science, Open Access Journals, Smart Metals; Who's That Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The claim of alternative practitioners to not treat disease labels but the whole patient...allows alternative practitioners to live in a fool’s paradise of quackery where they believe themselves to be protected from any challenges and demands for evidence."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Scientists have discovered the first evidence of a comet striking the earth – part of a comet nucleus.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers have discovered a method for inhibiting the propagation of prion proteins, potentially leading to a cure for mad cow and related diseases.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Physicists have created stable exotic calcium nuclei (with 20 protons and 34 neutrons), suggesting the existence of a previously unknown force operating at nuclear scales.

section.title: This Day in Skepticism: Chicago Fire
Science Sting on Open Access Journals

episode.title: Episode 429
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: World Teacher Day; News Items: New IPCC Report, Photographic the Soul, Chiropractor Breaks Baby's Neck, Black Hole Explosions and Hair; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Monsanto, Overpowered Studies; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "In an argument, you may silence your opponent by pressing an advantage of strength, or of wealth, or of education. But you do not really convince him. Though he is no longer saying anything, in his heart he still keeps to his opinion. The only way to make him change that opinion is to speak quietly and reasonably. When he understands that you are not trying to defeat him, but only to find the truth, he will listen to you and perhaps accept what you tell him."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: The most robust study to date finds that depression does not increase risk for developing cancer.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds that bystander CPR for out-of-hospital cardiac arrest more than doubles short and long term survival.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Scientists have discovered the gene variants that in most people determine left or right-handedness.

episode.title: Episode 428
episode.description: Interview with Jamie Williams; This Day in Skepticism: Thomas Crapper; News Items: GMO OK, Angry Internet, Warning Labels, When Black Holes Explode, Carbon Nanotube Computers; Who's That Noisy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "The grand aim of all science [is] to cover the greatest number of empirical facts by logical deduction from the smallest possible number of hypotheses or axioms."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: For the first time scientists have created “photonic molecules” – coaxing photons of light to interact with each other to form a new state of matter.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A recently published study of deep brain stimulation finds it effective for increasing empathy in subjects who rate highly on the psychopath scale.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Astronomers have discovered a new type of pulsar that regularly switches between radio and X-ray emissions.

episode.title: Episode 427
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: David Vetter; News Items: IgNobel 2013, Top Quarks End Universe, Alien Life on Earth, The Physics of Homosexuality, Regeneration; Who's That Noisy; Questions and E-mails: Quantum Energy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "No No. Be of good cheer. If science teaches us anything, it teaches us to accept our failures, as well as our successes, with quiet dignity and grace."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A new study finds that beauty sleep is real – patients who were treated for poor sleep were rated as more attractive following treatment.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Researchers find that cats infected with the toxoplasma parasite are more affectionate and likely to lick other animals, including humans, increasing the spread of the parasite.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Scientists have discovered a method for converting mature skin cells into stem cells with near perfect efficiency by removing a single protein.

episode.title: Episode 426
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: 9/11; News items: Motivated Numeracy, Arctic Ice, Robot Traders, Teenage Exorcists, Homeopathic Vaccines, Mission to Mars; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Bdellovibrio; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "When he found that his long cherished beliefs did not agree with the most precise observations, he accepted the uncomfortable facts. He preferred the hard truth to his dearest delusions, that is the heart of science."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: New research finds that hearing a salesperson flatter another customer causes a negative reaction to the salesperson but increases the desire to buy an expensive item.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A new study finds that subjects were more likely to purchase a lottery ticket if they had just spent money on an expensive item.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Researchers find that women are more likely to purchase expensive accessories when they feel threatened in their relationship, and that this strategy works because women are also less likely to pursue a man whose girlfriend has expensive accessories.

section.title: A Quickie With Bob: Mission to Mars

episode.title: Episode 425
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Last Thylacine; News Items: NASA Spiders, Chicken Wings and Penis Size, TCM for Flu, New Element 115; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Pox Parties, Aromatherapy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "Science is the only thing that disproves science, and it does it all the time."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A thorough review of published studies in Psychology found that only 5% of published replications confirm the prior results.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Studies have found that as many as 50% of published peer-reviewed research contains statistical errors, sometimes changing the conclusions of the study.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: In surveys, 34% of researchers admitted to questionable research practices themselves, and up to 72% in their colleagues.

episode.title: Episode 424
episode.description: Interview with Cara Santa Maria; This Day in Skepticism: Paul Ehrlich; News Items: Energized Water, Probiotics for Mental Health, Death by Iridology, Immortality; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Authority; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "A faith that cannot survive collision with the truth is not worth many regrets."
quote.by: Arthur C. Clarke, The Exploration of Space

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Acids taste sour, while bases taste bitter.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: The pH of spinal fluid averages from 4.5-5.5, mainly from the presence of carbonic acid.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: In a study of 20 soft drinks, RC cola was found to be the most acidic at a pH of 2.4.

item.title: Item #4
item.description: The world’s strongest acid, carborane, which is a million times more potent than sulphuric acid, is also one of the least corrosive.

episode.title: Episode 423
episode.description: Interview with Sanal Edamaruku; This Day in Skepticism: Vesuvius; News Items: No Proof of Creation, Area 51, Hydrating Beer, Indian Rationalist Shot Dead, Free Roaming Planets; Who's That Noisy; Your Questions and E-mails: Sugar and Hyperactivity; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "It is morally as bad not to care whether a thing is true or not, so long as it makes you feel good, as it is not to care how you got your money as long as you have got it."
quote.by: Edmund Way Teale in ’Circle of the Seasons’, quoted by Carl Sagan in ’The Demon-haunted World’

item.title: Item #1
item.description: Scientists have identified a blood test that can identify those at increased risk for suicide.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A recent study finds that heavy rains in Australia over 2010-2011 actually caused global sea levels to drop measurably.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: Breeders have produced a variety of chicken that lays cholesterol-free eggs.

episode.title: Episode 422
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Hazel Bishop; News Items: NDE Explained, TV Watching, Labor and Autism, Magenta Planet, Spontaneous Baby Combustion; Special Report: Onionated; Who's That Noisy; Name That Logical Fallacy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "It’s funny when people accuse science of being narrow merely because it asks for proof. Science expanded the number of elements from four to over 100. It expanded treatment options from bloodletting, herbs and purgatives to the untold riches we have today. It expanded the universe from a series of armillary spheres to the current, nigh-endless void. It expanded the number of worlds from two to billions upon billions. It expanded the age of the universe from 7,000 to 13.5 billion. Science expanded our senses from a tiny range of sound and light to an endless modulation of wavelengths revealing whole worlds we knew nothing about. It extended our senses from millimeters to angstroms, from kilometers to light years. Science discovered volcanoes under the oceans, terrible lizards who ruled our murine predecessors, asteroids that shattered the world, glaciers that circled the globe, the origins of man in ape rather than god. Science exposed the lie of vitalism, extended lives, cured cancer, discovered vitamins, discovered radiation (then found it was bad for us). And in the last group of discoveries, quacks were poised to kill the discoveries and loot their corpses."

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A recent study finds that listening to an emotional sermon can induce an out-of-body experience in susceptible people.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: A recent study finds that listening to an emotional sermon can induce an out-of-body experience in susceptible people.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: A new paper warns against “chemophobia,” the irrational fear of the ubiquitous and non-toxic chemicals found in our food and environment.

episode.title: Episode 419
episode.description: This Day in Skepticism: Insulin; News Items: Giant Virus, Gluten, Death Wave, The Pitch Drops, Revenge of the Conspiracy Theorists, Cassini Picture of Earth; Who's That Noisy; Name That Logical Fallacy; Science or Fiction

quote.text: "He is a barbarian, who thinks the customs of his tribe are the laws of nature."
quote.by: Caesar, from Caesar and Cleopatra, Act II, by George Bernard Shaw

item.title: Item #1
item.description: A recent study finds that occasional marijuana use increases alertness, probably through improved sleep quality.

item.title: Item #2
item.description: Scientists have discovered that the herpes simplex virus (HSV-1) is packed under pressure 8 times higher than a car tire, and uses that pressure to blast its DNA into the nucleus of cells.

item.title: Item #3
item.description: A new analysis finds that 2000 year old techniques for gold and silver plating produced results that cannot be achieved even with modern technology.
